commentary.line: Sri Lanka have opened their account in the tournament. However, this is certainly not a satisfying win as Afghanistan ran them very close. That's it from this game. We enjoyed bringing it to you. Switch tabs to get all the action from the India-South Africa match at the MCG. Take care. Goodbye!
Here are a few tweets
Russel Arnold: Few years on people will look back N say "hundred vs Afghan" but all will forget D true value/importance/class.. One of D best @MahelaJay
Nathan Bracken: Great performance by @ACBofficials. Almost there. So many promising signs
Rajneesh Gupta: Most hundreds in World Cup:6-Sachin Tendulkar 5-Ricky Ponting 4-Mark Waugh 4-Sourav Ganguly 4-MAHELA JAYAWARDENA #cwc15 #SLvsAFG
Gautam Bhimani: Magnificent fight from @ACBofficials but in the end the power and experience of Perera just built on that @MahelaJay special #SLvAFG
Mazher Arshad: Only 2nd time in ODI history that both openers are dismissed for Golden Ducks in ODI. Prev instance: Zimbabwe vs WI at Georgetown 2006.

Mathews: "Relieved, but I thought Afghanistan put us under a lot of pressure and we had to fight really hard until the last ball was bowled. To be honest, we need to raise our standards to compete against the top teams. It was a see-saw kind of a game. They started off brilliantly and then we pulled it back. They had been putting pressure right throughout the game and they have been playing brilliant cricket. So, credit should go to them. I was actually struggling to time the ball, but I knew that I had to stick there with Mahela to get some kind of partnership going and then for Thisara to come in and blast those 47 runs was unbelievable. We try and use Dimuth (Karunaratne) as a floater. When a wicket falls early on, we try and use him up the order. We've got heaps of experience, we have got Dilshan, Sangakkara and Mahela, so we can utilise them in pressure situations."

Nabi: "We started very well, but we were 30-40 runs short on that pitch. We bowled well for the first 10-15 overs and put pressure on the Sri Lankan guys. Also, I think we missed a few run-outs at the start. It's quite tough in a tight game and the boys played really well. Maybe, they batted well and again proved that they were a big team. The way Jayawardene and Mathews played, with discipline and did not take pressure and also they took the game away from us. Hopefully, we will play well in the next game. Dawlat, Hamid and Shapoor bowled brilliantly. Hopefully, they will be fit for the next game."

By removing both set batsmen in a space of 3 runs, Afghanistan came back strongly into the game. Thisara Perera and Jeevan Mendis survived a few close moments and Perera in particular, attacked the bowling to transfer the pressure back on Afghanistan's bowlers. The duo also recorded Sri Lanka's best ever 7th wicket stand in World Cups and eventually got them past the line with 10 balls to spare. Hamid was the pick of the bowlers with three wickets, while Shapoor and Dawlat bagged one each.

Chasing 233, Afghanistan removed both openers, Thirimanne and Dilshan for first-ball ducks - this was only the second time in ODIs that both openers were dismissed for golden ducks. Sangakkara too went very early, despite getting lucky with a couple of run-out chances. Jayawardene shared a small partnership with Karunaratne before the latter threw it away. Captain Mathews then combined well with Jayawardene and shared a 126-run stand for the 5th wicket. Jayawardene recorded his 19th ODI hundred - also his 4th hundred in World Cups - in the process. However, Mathews fell 6 runs short of a fifty and soon was followed by Jayawardene, who gifted his wicket away to Hamid and walked off in disbelief.

Jayawardene: "Yeah, I think we probably dodged a bullet today. All credit to Afghanistan, I thought they batted really well in tough conditions. And upfront bowled beautifully. They bowled upto the batsmen, got a bit of movement and put us under a lot of pressure. Big relief, yes! They got the pace, they got a bit of movement as well and if there is something in the wicket, they are a handful and have played a lot of international cricket. It's not a big gap between the top countries and the others. In that situation I wasn't worrying about the other end, I just wanted to make sure that I batted 50 overs, but the disappointing fact was I couldn't finish the game off. Angelo (Mathews) batted really well for that partnership and Thisara (Perera) came and finished it off for us. All in all it was a good effort, but we have a bit of work to do. It was a bit of a wait after the first game, now we have two quick games coming up which is probably a good thing for us rather than sitting around."
Jayawardene is the Man of the Match

A heartbreaking result for Afghanistan. They came so close but couldn't seal the game. With the top three gone for next to nothing, they would have fancied their chances, but Jayawardene used his experience to bail Sri Lanka out of trouble.

48.2   Nabi to T Perera, FOUR, that's it! Sri Lanka have avoided an embarrassing loss. Short and outside off stump, Perera rocks back and muscles it hard over extra-cover for a one-bounce four. This is a fine innings from the all-rounder, who was picked ahead of Nuwan Kulasekara
48.1   Nabi to T Perera, no run, outside off stump this time, Perera backs away and lets it go
48.1   Nabi to J Mendis, 2 wides, the captain fires this fast and down the leg-side, Mendis tries to help it on its way but misses. The keeper fumbles and they take an extra run
Mohammad Nabi [5.0-0-22-0] is back into the attack
This is a record 7th wicket stand for Sri Lanka in World Cups.

47.4   Hamid to T Perera, 2 runs, this is excellent cricket from the duo. As soon as he dug out the yorker towards mid-on, he raced calling 'two, two, two.' Mid-on was on the boundary and Mendis was quick to return back for the second

47.3   Hamid to T Perera, 2 runs, a misfield at mid-wicket, Shapoor is the man, gives Sri Lanka a couple of runs. Short of a length delivery on the leg stump, Perera mistimes the pull, the fielder dives to his left, but doesn't stop the ball

Drama! The umpire rules Mendis out caught behind after a long thought. Mendis shakes his head and reviews straightaway. In fact, the keeper hardly went up in his appeal. Snicko is absolutely dead as Rameez Raja would say. The decision has been overturned.
Hamid Hassan [8.0-0-34-3] is back into the attack

Has that carried to the keeper? Not out says the umpire.

Sri Lanka have scored 19 runs in the last two overs. That should ease the nerves a bit. Just 26 needed off 4 overs now.

He was trying to play it finer, but hit it too well. M Jayawardene c Nawroz b Hamid 100(120) [4s-8 6s-1]

Short of a length delivery just outside off stump, Mathews turns it just beside the pitch towards short mid-wicket, the fielder rushes in, grabs the ball and fires a direct-hit at the bowler's end to catch Mathews short. End of a fine 126-run partnership. Mathews run out (Nabi) 44(81) [4s-2]
Shapoor to Mathews, THATS OUT!! Run Out!!
It's a direct-hit and Mathews is short of his crease. Brilliant bit of fielding gives Afghanistan the breakthrough.

Drinks are on the field now. Mahela Jayawardene has used his experience and played a great hand here for Sri Lanka. He has been very patient, but when the bad ball has come, he has not been shy to send it to the boundary. Captain Angelo Mathews too has given good support and the duo have added almost 100 runs for the 5th wicket. Afghanistan have to be disciplined with their bowling.

Time for a drinks break! It has been all Afghanistan till now. But, can they keep going? They started well with the bat as well, but couldn't sustain through the 50 overs. For Sri Lanka, a lot will depend on this pair. If they can get them to touching distance of the target, then the likes of Thisara and Mendis can flex their muscles.

Welcome back.. Sri Lanka did well to pull things after the 88-run stand between Stankizai and Shenwari. Afghanistan will be ruining the fact that they could not capitalise on the start. However, it is now upto their bowlers to try and make a match of it.

A disastrous batting powerplay - in which they scored just 10 runs and lost two key wickets - meant they lost their way. The lower-order then dropped anchor, before losing wickets in a hurry as they tried to accelerate in the death overs. Mathews and Malinga picked three wickets each, but Lakmal (10-1-36-2) was the pick of the bowlers. 233 should not be a stiff challenge for Sri Lanka, but Afghanistan have a good pace attack. Take a break and join us back in a short while for the run chase.

Again, as coach Andy Moles said, Afghanistan batted well for 30 odd overs and lost the plot thereafter. Although they lost openers Mangal and Ahmadi in quick succession after a decent start, Stanikzai and Shenwari steadied Afghanistan with a fine fifty-plus partnership. Stanikzai also registered a fifty in the process - his 5th in ODIs. However, he threw his wicket away and Shenwari too followed him soon.

49.4   Malinga to Zazai, out Caught by Herath!! Afghanistan are bowled out for 232, Malinga ends with three. Slower delivery outside off stump, Zazai goes across the stumps and attempts a slog, gets a thick outside edge, Herath runs back and to his right from short third man to complete the catch. Dilshan was also approaching the ball from backward point and they almost collided. Zazai c Herath b Malinga 19(38) [4s-1]

Afghanistan openers make their way out to the middle. Malinga is already on top of the mark. Jeevan Mendis starts off the countdown. Senanayake says let the battle begin. Mathews on the attack, he has three slips in place.

The teams line-up for the national anthems. It is the Sri Lankan anthem which is played out first, followed by Afghanistan's anthem. There are plenty of people donning the Sri Lankan jersey in the ground.

Pitch Report: "New Zealand bowled out Scotland for 142 on this very surface and that is the reason Sri Lanka have opted to bowl. It has browned a bit, but there is still a good covering of grass. I think it will play a little bit better, but it will still be very tough early on. Quite short boundaries, the outfield looks very nice. We had a bit of rain last night, so it's lushed up a little. It might not be as quick as it normally is and it will be tough for the first 10-15 overs with the bat," reckons Simon Doull
Teams:

Afghanistan (Playing XI): Nawroz Mangal, Javed Ahmadi, Asghar Stanikzai, Samiullah Shenwari, Mohammad Nabi(c), Najibullah Zadran, Afsar Zazai(w), Mirwais Ashraf, Dawlat Zadran, Hamid Hassan, Shapoor Zadran

Sri Lanka (Playing XI): Lahiru Thirimanne, Tillakaratne Dilshan, Kumar Sangakkara(w), Mahela Jayawardene, Angelo Mathews(c), Dimuth Karunaratne, Jeevan Mendis, Thisara Perera, Rangana Herath, Lasith Malinga, Suranga Lakmal
Sri Lanka have won the toss and have opted to field

Mathews: "We had a lot of time to prepare ourselves for this game, to work on the areas that we need to improve and we have been training so hard for the past few days. I will have a bowl first. It swings a little bit early on and we are playing four seamers so we will look to exploit the conditions. This has always been a wicket that swings and seams a little bit. One change, Nuwan Kulasekara is out, Thisara Perera comes in."

Nabi: "Yeah, from the last four months he (Andy Moles, coach) has joined us, he has helped us prepare well. We also wanted to bowl first because last night there was rain and the wicket was covered. There is a bit of grass as well and also the weather is cold. Hopefully, we will bat well. We have prepared well and worked on our plans. The boys have worked hard. We have one change, Aftab is not playing, Dawlat is playing today."

We know that the ball swings around at the University Oval and with a bit of moisture because of the overnight rain, it wouldn't be surprising to see teams opting to bowl first. The toss is not too far away. Lot's more coming up. Stay tuned...
Afghanistan

On the other hand, Mohammad Nabi's men could not live up to the expectations against Bangladesh as Mashrafe Mortaza and Co. registered an easy win over Afghanistan in Canberra. Bangladesh won the toss and opted to bat, but Afghanistan were impressive with the ball, until they met Mushfiqur Rahim and Shakib Al Hasan as the duo added over 100 runs for the 5th wicket. However, the Afghans closed out the innings in grand style as Bangladesh lost their last 6 wickets for just 34 runs to be bowled out for 267. In their run chase, Afghanistan were reduced to 3/3 in no time and from that point, could never really keep up with the asking rate. Eventually, Bangladesh bowled them out for 162 to enjoy a 105-run win.

Speaking after the match Coach Andy Moles stressed on the importance for competing hard throughout the game. "One of the issues we've had is that we do well with bat and ball for 35 overs and it's that extra 15 overs where we need to work on our concentration levels, our discipline, our execution and it's something we have spoken about regularly," Moles said.
Sri Lanka

The 2011 runners-up did not have a great start to their campaign as they lost badly to New Zealand in the tournament opener. After opting to bowl first, Angelo Mathews' bowlers found it tough to control Brendon McCullum, Kane Williamson and Corey Anderson as the trio scored fifties to help the Black Caps post a massive total on the board. In reply, apart from Lahiru Thirimanne, none of the Sri Lankan batsmen could make valuable contributions and eventually, they went on to lose by a massive margin of 98 runs.

Sri Lanka, who have played here twice before, are tagged as favourites to win this contest and captain Angelo Mathews has said that his side has prepared well and is not taking Afghanistan lightly. "We have worked extremely hard in the past few days to prepare ourselves for this game because we have to take it very seriously. We can't be complacent and we are well-prepared for the challenge."

We are at the University Oval in Dunedin today for this Group A encounter between Afghanistan and Sri Lanka. Both teams lost their first game of the tournament and will be keen to open their account today. First things first. There was a lot of rain on Saturday in Dunedin, but the weather has cleared up and the radar looks good for today. So, we don't have to worry about or entertain thoughts of a washout.

Preview:

Sri Lanka started their campaign on an abject note against New Zealand in the opening game of ICC Cricket World Cup 2015. That 98-run loss will be rankling them and Afghanistan will be bracing themselves for the backlash. Sri Lanka will have to win, and convincingly at that, against Afghanistan to regain confidence and assert themselves as contenders for the World Cup. The one-week break would have helped the team regain composure but Afghanistan will be no pushovers.

Mohammad Nabi, the captain, and coach Andy Moles have emphasised on various occasions that Afghanistan are not there to just compete but to try and win games. Like their opponents, Afghanistan too come in to this game on the back of a 105-run loss against Bangladesh. The batsmen came a cropper after a decent bowling effort and Afghanistan will be gunning to prove that they are ready to fight against the big teams.

Venue: University Oval, Dunedin

Date: February 22, 2015

Time: 0330 HRS IST

Weather and pitch conditions:

If the previous game at Dunedin is anything to go by, expect some help for the seamers. New Zealand bowled Scotland out for a low total but lost as many as 7 wickets in chase of a lowly 142. The short boundaries will also aid the big hitters. It is expected to be a sunny Sunday and neither team will mind that.

Team news:

Sri Lanka

Nuwan Kulasekara might be replaced by youngster Dushmantha Chameera for Sri Lanka. Kulasekara went for 78 runs in his eight overs in the game against New Zealand but the rest are likely to retain their place.

Probable XI: Tillakaratne Dilshan, Lahiru Thirimanne, Kumar Sangakkara(w), Mahela Jayawardene, Angelo Mathews(c), Dimuth Karunaratne, Jeevan Mendis, Dushmantha Chameera, Suranga Lakmal, Rangana Herath, Lasith Malinga

Afghanistan

Afghanistan might look at tinkering their batting order after an abysmal collapse but are likely to go in with the same eleven that played Bangladesh.

Probable XI: Afsar Zazai(w), Javed Ahmadi, Nawroz Mangal, Asghar Stanikzai, Samiullah Shenwari, Mohammad Nabi(c), Najibullah Zadran, Mirwais Ashraf, AftabAlam, Shapoor Zadran, Hamid Hassan

Watch out for:

Seventeen-year old Usman Ghani played confidently in the warm-up game against India. He will like the short boundaries at Dunedin and could be the key for Afghanistan to get off to a good start while batting.

Lasith Malinga will be a tricky bowler to face for newcomers. Tracking the ball will be a challenge for Afghanistan as the Sri Lankan's pacer's slingy action is nothing close to what you'd face in practice. He has blown away many a side once he finds rhythm and Sri Lanka will be hoping that he finds it against Afghanistan.

Quotes

You can't take them lightly because they can upset a team, and they've got nothing to lose. They'll just come out here and try to be positive and aggressive - Angelo Mathews guards against complacency
Teams:

Sri Lanka (From): Lahiru Thirimanne, Tillakaratne Dilshan, Kumar Sangakkara(w), Mahela Jayawardene, Dimuth Karunaratne, Angelo Mathews(c), Jeevan Mendis, Nuwan Kulasekara, Rangana Herath, Lasith Malinga, Suranga Lakmal, Thisara Perera, Dinesh Chandimal, Sachithra Senanayake, Dushmantha Chameera

Afghanistan (From): Javed Ahmadi, Afsar Zazai(w), Nawroz Mangal, Asghar Stanikzai, Samiullah Shenwari, Mohammad Nabi(c), Najibullah Zadran, Mirwais Ashraf, Aftab Alam, Hamid Hassan, Shapoor Zadran, Usman Ghani, Gulbadin Naib, Dawlat Zadran, Nasir Jamal
